definition: Overview of the direct immunofluorescence technique used for diagnosing immunobullous diseases, connective tissue diseases, and vasculitis.
clinical: Biopsy site selection is critical: perilesional (within 1cm of lesion) is preferred to avoid epidermal detachment. Avoid the blister itself. For connective tissue disease, biopsy site depends on the specific query (involved vs. uninvolved skin).
pathogenesis: Detects in vivo deposition of immunoglobulins and complement factors in tissue.
ancillary_studies: Transport media: Michel's (ammonium sulfate) or Saline (short term). DO NOT use Formalin (fixes immunoglobulins). Standard Panel: IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, Fibrinogen.

related_figures.legend: Diagram illustrating perilesional biopsy technique. (Time: 175s)
Standard 5-stain panel setup: IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, Fibrinogen. (Time: 245s)
Comparison of tissue antigen visualization using FITC conjugated antibodies. (Time: 276s)

definition: The most common autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease affecting the elderly.
clinical: Elderly patients (>60). Chronic course. Pruritic, tense, deflated blisters. Often associated with urticaria. Can be drug-induced.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against hemidesmosome components: BPAG1 (BP230) and BPAG2 (BP180/Type XVII Collagen).
macroscopic: Tense blisters on normal or erythematous/urticarial skin.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear deposition of IgG and/or C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction (BMZ).
differential_diagnosis: Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita, Bullous Lupus, Pemphigoid Gestationis.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation showing tense, deflated blisters and urticarial plaques. (Time: 401s)
H&E showing subepidermal split with numerous eosinophils. (Time: 434s)
DIF showing linear IgG pattern at the basement membrane zone. (Time: 439s)

definition: A variant of bullous pemphigoid occurring during pregnancy (formerly Herpes Gestationis).
clinical: Pregnant women (usually late pregnancy). Abrupt onset, intensely pruritic. Urticarial plaques and bullae, often periumbilical. Spontaneous remission postpartum; recurs in future pregnancies. Risk of premature birth.
macroscopic: Urticarial plaques and blisters on trunk/abdomen.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with eosinophils (similar to BP).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear C3 (and often IgG) at the dermo-epidermal junction.
differential_diagnosis: Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy (PUPPP), Bullous Pemphigoid.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation in pregnancy showing urticarial and bullous lesions. (Time: 496s)

definition: A chronic, scarring autoimmune blistering disease predominantly affecting mucous membranes.
clinical: Affects age >60. Chronic and progressive. Sites: Scalp (Brunsting-Perry variant, scarring alopecia), Oral (lateral tongue ulcers, desquamative gingivitis), Ocular (symblepharon, risk of blindness), Genital, Esophageal.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against various BMZ antigens (BP180, Laminin 332, etc.).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgG and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction.
differential_diagnosis: Bullous Pemphigoid, Erosive Lichen Planus, Pemphigus Vulgaris.
prognosis_and_prediction: High risk of blindness if ocular involvement. Often refractory to mild therapy; may require dapsone or cytotoxic agents.

Oral involvement showing erosions on the lateral tongue. (Time: 587s)
Ocular involvement with scarring (symblepharon). (Time: 604s)

definition: A distinct subepidermal blistering disease often clinically resembling bullous pemphigoid or dermatitis herpetiformis.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against p200 antigen (Laminin gamma-1) in the lower lamina lucida.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with Neutrophils (unlike classic BP which has eosinophils).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgG/C3 at BMZ (looks like BP). Salt Split Skin: Maps to the Dermal side.
differential_diagnosis: Bullous Pemphigoid, Dermatitis Herpetiformis, Linear IgA.

related_figures.legend: H&E showing neutrophils in a subepidermal blister; DIF is linear. (Time: 641s)

definition: A rare, chronic, mechanobullous autoimmune blistering disease targeting collagen VII.
clinical: Trauma-induced blistering, scarring, milia. Two types: Classic (non-inflammatory, mechanobullous) and Inflammatory (mimics BP). High rate of oral/ocular involvement (30-50%).
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against Type VII Collagen (anchoring fibrils).
macroscopic: Tense hemorrhagic blisters, erosions, scarring on trauma-prone sites.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgG/C3 at BMZ. Salt Split Skin: Localization to the Dermal floor (u-serrated pattern on direct IF is also described in literature).
prognosis_and_prediction: Refractory to treatment; associated with Crohn's disease.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation showing scarring and erosions on hands. (Time: 692s)
Hemorrhagic tense blisters indicating deep dermal separation. (Time: 720s)

definition: A blistering eruption occurring in patients with established Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
clinical: Patient with SLE criteria. Acute onset of tense blisters on normal or erythematous skin. Photosensitive.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against Type VII Collagen (anchoring fibrils).
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with neutrophils (can mimic Dermatitis Herpetiformis).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Granular or Linear IgG/IgA/C3 at BMZ (Lupus Band). Salt Split Skin: Dermal floor (if anti-type VII Abs present).
prognosis_and_prediction: Responsive to Dapsone and oral corticosteroids.

related_figures.legend: H&E showing neutrophils at the DEJ (mimicking DH) and DIF showing granular deposition. (Time: 796s)

definition: A cutaneous manifestation of gluten sensitivity (Celiac disease).
clinical: Intensely pruritic grouped papulovesicles on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, buttocks). Excoriations common. Associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy. HLA-DQ2/DQ8 association.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Granular IgA deposition in dermal papillae.
differential_diagnosis: Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis, Scabies, Eczema.
prognosis_and_prediction: Responds to gluten-free diet and Dapsone.

related_figures.legend: Grouped papules and excoriations on the elbow. (Time: 874s)
H&E showing neutrophilic microabscess in the dermal papilla. (Time: 894s)
DIF showing granular IgA in dermal papillae. (Time: 903s)

definition: An autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease characterized by linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane.
clinical: Annular or polycyclic blisters ('Cluster of Jewels' sign). Affects adults and children (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood). Can be drug-induced (Vancomycin). Mucosal involvement common (30-50%).
macroscopic: Blisters arranged in a ring (rosette) pattern.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with neutrophils at the dermo-epidermal junction.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgA band at the dermo-epidermal junction.

related_figures.legend: Annular blistering ('Crown of Jewels') presentation. (Time: 947s)
H&E showing neutrophils at the DEJ. (Time: 973s)
DIF showing linear IgA band at the basement membrane. (Time: 982s)

definition: The most common porphyria, caused by a defect in uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
clinical: Photosensitivity. Tense blisters, erosions, crusts, and scarring on sun-exposed sites (hands, face). Hypertrichosis, hyperpigmentation. Associated with Hepatitis C, alcohol, estrogens, iron overload.
pathogenesis: Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency (inherited or acquired). Accumulation of uroporphyrins.
macroscopic: Blisters, milia, scarring on dorsal hands.
microscopic: Cell-poor subepidermal blister. 'Festooning' of dermal papillae.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear, broad, shaggy IgG, C3, and Fibrinogen at BMZ and around dermal blood vessels. Urine/Serum Porphyrins elevated.

related_figures.legend: Blisters and erosions on the dorsal hands. (Time: 1045s)
H&E showing cell-poor subepidermal blister with festooning. (Time: 1063s)
DIF showing strong homogeneous staining of vessel walls and BMZ. (Time: 1078s)

definition: A severe autoimmune intraepidermal blistering disease affecting skin and mucous membranes.
clinical: Flaccid blisters on normal skin, painful erosions. Oral mucosa almost always involved (often presenting sign). Positive Nikolsky sign.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against Desmoglein 3 (mucosal dominant) and Desmoglein 1 (mucocutaneous).
microscopic: Suprabasilar acantholysis. 'Row of tombstones' (basal layer remains attached). Eosinophils common.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Intercellular IgG and C3 in a 'chicken wire' or 'net-like' pattern throughout the epidermis.
differential_diagnosis: Pemphigus Foliaceus, Hailey-Hailey Disease, Grover Disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: Can be fatal if untreated. Treat with systemic steroids and immunosuppressants (Rituximab).

related_figures.legend: Clinical showing flaccid blisters and erosions on the trunk. (Time: 1255s)
H&E showing suprabasilar acantholysis and 'tombstoning'. (Time: 1311s)
DIF showing intercellular 'net-like' IgG deposition. (Time: 1326s)

clinical: Scaly, crusted erosions in seborrheic distribution (face, scalp, chest, back). No oral involvement. 'Cornflakes' appearance.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Intercellular IgG and C3, often more intense in superficial epidermis.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation on the face (nose). (Time: 1387s)
H&E showing superficial acantholysis in the granular layer. (Time: 1392s)
DIF showing superficial intercellular IgG pattern. (Time: 1414s)

definition: Direct immunofluorescence patterns in Lupus Erythematosus (LE), primarily the Lupus Band Test.
clinical: SLE: Malar rash, photosensitivity, systemic symptoms. DLE: Discoid plaques, scarring alopecia.
microscopic: Vacuolar interface dermatitis, superficial and deep perivascular/periadnexal lymphocytic infiltrate, mucin.
ancillary_studies: DIF (Lupus Band Test): Granular IgG, IgM, and C3 along the dermo-epidermal junction. SLE: Positive in involved AND uninvolved sun-exposed skin. DLE: Positive only in involved skin.

related_figures.legend: Clinical showing severe photosensitive eruption. (Time: 1486s)
DIF showing granular 'Lupus Band' at the DEJ. (Time: 1512s)
In vivo ANA phenomenon: Speckled nuclear fluorescence in keratinocytes (seen in MCTD or high-titer SLE). (Time: 1618s)

definition: Small vessel vasculitis mediated by immune complex deposition.
clinical: Palpable purpura, typically on lower legs.
pathogenesis: Immune complex deposition in vessel walls.
microscopic: Neutrophils within and around vessel walls, fibrinoid necrosis, leukocytoclasia (nuclear dust).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Perivascular C3, IgM, or IgG deposition.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of palpable purpura on legs. (Time: 1656s)
H&E showing LCV and DIF showing perivascular C3. (Time: 1669s)

definition: A subtype of leukocytoclastic vasculitis characterized by IgA deposition.
clinical: Palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgia, renal involvement. Affects children and adults.
microscopic: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis (indistinguishable from non-IgA LCV on H&E).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Granular IgA deposition in vessel walls.

related_figures.legend: DIF showing granular IgA in vessel walls. (Time: 1697s)

definition: An inflammatory condition of skin and mucous membranes with characteristic interface dermatitis.
clinical: Cutaneous: Pruritic, purple, polygonal papules. Oral: Reticular (Wickham striae), erosive, or atrophic.
microscopic: Hyperkeratosis, wedge-shaped hypergranulosis, irregular acanthosis ('saw-tooth'), band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at DEJ, Civatte bodies.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Shaggy, fibrillar Fibrinogen deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction and on Civatte bodies (Cytoid bodies).
differential_diagnosis: Lichenoid Drug Eruption, Lupus Erythematosus, Graft vs Host Disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic course, particularly oral erosive form.

related_figures.legend: H&E showing dense band-like lymphocytic infiltrate. (Time: 1768s)
